title: Significant learning points from OCWC’s OER search engine
segmentation: Alright, so I have a lot of flies but do not be afraid.
I'm not going to go through all of them.
OK, so the title of this talk is it significant learning points from Open Courseware consortium Zoe?
Our search engine anwen?
Go to our website.
You see a search engine like this.
You can search for courses.
And we also have a data dump for all the courses, so I.
Figured it would be really nice to analyze the data that we have an find out in what discipline we have.
Courses are they balanced in any way or find out the languages that oh yards are in?
Does the courseware reflect personality of the institution at all?

Anne, let our members know that data is very, very important, so some of you whose institutions are the consortiums Members have already heard from me that you should be giving us more data on the courses.
Now this.
This is what the data looks like on an Excel sheet course URL.
The course title course description, what language it's in, the institution's name.
So I figured, OK, what I'm going to do is.
I'll run the course description through a translator and see what kind of keywords we can get.
I did that and the course descriptions ended up telling us nothing.
Course descriptions were filled with.
Junk words like author, course, and no matter how many words I took out of it, I didn't get anything significant, so I went back.
Anne had an analysis of the course titles.
I ran them through.
The transplant, an automatic translator.
And then we went through a text filtering and then run it through on our program to get a word cloud from it.
And this is what it look likes.
What it looks like on.
By language, you've got English.
You have health.
In the center and turns out that we have a lot of courses from Johns Hopkins School of Public Health and that is why we have helped.
And then you see physics, chemistry, education, introduction.
See big words like that in Spanish.
The most frequent words that came out of the courses were systems, information, computers, engineering.
In Chinese, in Slovenian you see certain keywords that really stick out.
In Chinese you have computer historical use the Confucius Medical.
Slovenian.
You see the war, Slovenia business processes?
Now this is the word cloud by institution.
Hokkaido University from Japan has the best course data that we have, and this is what their course title look like.
On the right hand side we have.
The word cloud from national to University from Taiwan.
And for national title University you see a lot of mathematics, linear programming etc.
This is from Middle East Technical University and Johns Hopkins School of Public Health.
So you get to see this a little more in depth and slowly tomorrow at the poster session.
I'm not going to be talking about.
I'm not going to be spending too much time on this.
However, there are certain conclusions or certain points that we can draw from this.
So many early adopters of open courseware have courseware.
Focus on science is.
It's probably because MIT's brand open courseware and the relationship in the network that early adopters had with MIT influenced what courses others would make.
Discipline influenced by First Department that adopted open courseware.
This was very obvious in cases of Taiwanese universities.
In others.
Now.
That was a very simple conclusion.

My real point was that I wanted to ask you to share course data with us because you all know that in Ovr discover ability and having people be able to search for courses that they need is really important.
So this is what I want to talk about tomorrow during the poster session, and I hope to see a lot of you there.
Thank you.
